sen.j: 伏見宮邦頼親王（ふしみのみや くによりしんのう、享保18年10月28日 (旧暦)（1733年12月4日） - 享和2年9月8日 (旧暦)（1802年10月4日））は、江戸時代の皇族。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori (December 4, 1733 - October 4, 1802) was an Imperial family member in Edo Period.
Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori (December 4, 1733 - October 4, 1802) was a member of the Imperial family in the Edo Period.
sen.cmt: In Edo Period -> in the Edo Period
sen.e: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori (December 4, 1733 - October 4, 1802) was a member of the Imperial family in the Edo Period.

sen.j: 伏見宮第18代。
sen.e: He was the 18th prince of Fushimi no miya.
He was the 18th head of the Fushiminomiya family.
sen.cmt: 「第18代伏見宮家当主」と解釈し、英文を書き換えました。
sen.e: He was the 18th head of the Fushiminomiya family.

sen.j: 伏見宮貞建親王の第二王子。
sen.e: He was the second son of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadataka.
He was the second son of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadataka.
He was the second son of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadataka.

sen.j: 幼称ははじめ孝宮、後に堯宮と改める。
sen.e: His childhood name was Takanomiya.
sen.cmt: 「孝宮」、「堯宮」はともに「たかのみや」と読みます。
sen.e: His childhood name was Taka no miya; firstly written '孝宮', later in different Japanese characters '堯宮'.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記が違うため、訳に反映しました。
sen.e: His childhood name was Taka no miya; firstly written '孝宮', later in different Japanese characters '堯宮'.

sen.j: 寛保2年（1742年）勧修寺に入り、勧修寺宮尊孝入道親王の附弟となる。
sen.e: In 1742, he was accepted at Kaju-ji Temple and became a disciple of Nyudo Shinno Kajujinomiya Sonko.
In 1742, he entered Kaju-ji Temple and became a disciple of priestly Imperial Prince Kajujinomiya Sonko.
sen.cmt: 入道親王の英訳を変更しました。
sen.e: In 1742, he entered Kaju-ji Temple and became a disciple of priestly Imperial Prince Kajujinomiya Sonko.

sen.j: 延享2年（1745年）11月勧修寺を相続。
sen.e: In November, 1745, he succeeded to Kanju-ji Temple.
In November 1745, he succeeded to the chief priest of Kanju-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 門跡の役職を継いだと解釈し、変更しました。
sen.e: In November 1745, he succeeded to the chief priest of Kanju-ji Temple.

sen.j: 同年12月桜町天皇の猶子となり、延享3年（1746年）5月親王宣下。
sen.e: In December, 1745, he was adopted by Emperor Sakuramachi, and in May, 1746, he was given the title of Imperial Prince.
In December 1745, he was adopted by Emperor Sakuramachi, and in June 1746, he was given the title of Imperial Prince.
sen.cmt: 延享3年（1746年）5月 は新暦の6月です。
sen.e: In December 1745, he was adopted by Emperor Sakuramachi, and in June 1746, he was given the title of Imperial Prince.

sen.j: 初名は徳明（のりあきら）。
sen.e: He was first named Noriakira.
He was firstly named Noriakira.
He was firstly named Noriakira.

sen.j: 勧修寺に入寺得度し寛宝入道親王を名乗る。
sen.e: He entered Kaju-ji Temple and was renamed Nyudo Shinno Kanpo.
He entered the Buddhist priesthood at Kaju-ji Temple and called himself priestly Imperial Prince Kanpo.
sen.cmt: 入道親王の英訳を変更しました。
sen.e: He entered the Buddhist priesthood at Kaju-ji Temple and called himself priestly Imperial Prince Kanpo.

sen.j: 延享5年（1748年）東大寺別当。
sen.e: In 1748, he became Betto (the head priest) of Todai-ji Temple.
In 1748, he became Betto (the head priest) of Todai-ji Temple.
In 1748, he became Betto (the head priest) of Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 安永3年（1774年）6月に伏見宮貞行親王が薨去し、伏見宮家が空主となったため、同年11月13日後桃園天皇の勅命により還俗し宮家を相続、名を邦頼と賜り改めて親王宣下を蒙る。
sen.e: After Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadamochi passed away in June, 1774, there was no heir to the Fushiminomiya family, and therefore by the order of Emperor Gomomozono he returned to secular life and succeeded to Fushimi no miya on November 13, 1774 receiving the title of Imperial Prince again with his name changed to Kuniyori.

After Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadamochi passed away in July 1774, as there was no heir to the Fushiminomiya family, he returned to the secular life following the order of Emperor Gomomozono and succeeded to the Fushiminomiya family on December 15th of the same year receiving the title of Imperial Prince again with his name changed to Kuniyori.
sen.cmt: 安永3年（1774年）6月は新暦で7月です。同年11月13日は12月15日です。Fushiminomiya family -> Fushimi no miya family
sen.e: After Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadamochi passed away in July 1774, as there was no heir to the Fushiminomiya family, he returned to the secular life following the order of Emperor Gomomozono and succeeded to the Fushiminomiya family on December 15th of the same year receiving the title of Imperial Prince again with his name changed to Kuniyori.

sen.j: 安永4年（1775年）2月元服し、兵部省卿に任ぜられる。
sen.e: In February, 1775, his coming of age ceremony was celebrated, he was appointed Hyobusho (Ministry of military) Kyo.
In March 1775, as his coming of age ceremony was held, he was appointed to Hyobusho-kyo (Minister of military).
sen.cmt: 安永4年（1775年）2月は新暦で3月です。Hyobusho Kyo -> Hyobusho-kyo
sen.e: In March 1775, as his coming of age ceremony was held, he was appointed to Hyobusho-kyo (Minister of military).

sen.j: 安永7年（1778年）12月二品に叙せられる。
sen.e: In December, 1778, he was granted Nihon (the second rank of Imperial Prince).
In January 1779, he was granted Nihon (the second rank of Imperial Prince).
sen.cmt: 安永7年（1778年）12月は新暦で1779年1月です。
sen.e: In January 1779, he was granted Nihon (the second rank of Imperial Prince).

sen.j: ところが、安永8年（1779年）に後桃園天皇が男子を残さずに死亡すると、邦頼親王が天皇を毒殺したとする風説が流され、京都所司代や後桜町上皇までが乗り出す騒ぎになったが、間もなくその無実が判明する。
sen.e: However, in 1779, when Emperor Gomomozono died without leaving any son, there was a rumor that Imperial Prince Kuniyori might have poisoned him, which sparked an uproar among people such as Kyoto shoshidai (the Kyoto deputy) and the Retired Emperor Gosakuramachi, but finally Kuniyori was vindicated after a while.

However, in 1779 when Emperor Gomomozono died without leaving an heir, there was a rumor that Imperial Prince Kuniyori might have poisoned him, which sparked uproar among people such as Kyoto shoshidai (the Kyoto deputy) and the Retired Emperor Gosakuramachi, but Kuniyori's innocence was soon vindicated.
sen.cmt: 男子を残さず -> 後継ぎを残さず と解釈し、英文を書き換えました。
sen.e: However, in 1779 when Emperor Gomomozono died without leaving an heir, there was a rumor that Imperial Prince Kuniyori might have poisoned him, which sparked uproar among people such as Kyoto shoshidai (the Kyoto deputy) and the Retired Emperor Gosakuramachi, but Kuniyori's innocence was soon vindicated.

sen.j: 天明7年（1787年）鷹司輔平の女昌子と結婚する。
sen.e: In 1787, he married Masako TAKATSUKASA, a daughter of Sukehira TAKATSUKASA.
In 1787, he married Masako TAKATSUKASA, a daughter of Sukehira TAKATSUKASA.
In 1787, he married Masako TAKATSUKASA, a daughter of Sukehira TAKATSUKASA.

sen.j: 天明8年（1788年）京都を襲った大火では、宮邸を焼亡する憂き目にあった。
sen.e: In 1788, he suffered misery from burning his palace down by a great fire hit in Kyoto.
In 1788, he had to undergo the hardship of losing his palace which was destroyed by the great fire that hit the city of Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 英文を書き換えました。
sen.e: In 1788, he had to undergo the hardship of losing his palace which was destroyed by the great fire that hit the city of Kyoto.

sen.j: 享和2年（1802年）9月7日一品に叙せられるが、翌9月8日薨去。
sen.e: On September 7, 1802, he was granted Ippon (the first rank of Imperial Prince), but passed away on September 7, 1802.
On October 3, 1802, he was granted Ippon (the first rank of Imperial Prince), but passed away on the next day, October 4th.
sen.cmt: 享和2年（1802年）9月7日は新暦で10月3日です。
sen.e: On October 3, 1802, he was granted Ippon (the first rank of Imperial Prince), but passed away on the next day, October 4th.
He died at the age of 70.
Died at the age of 70.
sen.cmt: 用語統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: Died at the age of 70.

sen.j: 法名は究竟覚院。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Kyugakuin.
His posthumous Buddhist name is Kukyokakuin.
sen.cmt: 法名として「究竟覚院」の読みは不明ですが、「究竟覚」を「くきょうかく（仏語、悟りの極地）」という言葉があるので、法名の読みを変更しました。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Kukyokakuin.

sen.j: 王子女に伏見宮貞敬親王、輪王寺宮公澄入道親王、薫子女王などがいる。
sen.e: He had children including Emperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki, Nyudo Shinno Rinnojinomiya Kocho and Princess Taruko.
sen.cmt: 貞敬は正しくは「さだゆき」と読みます。
sen.e: He had children including Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki, priestly Imperial Prince Rinnojinomiya Kocho, Princess Taruko and others.
sen.cmt: Emperial -> Imperial入道親王の英訳を変更しました。
sen.e: He had children including Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki, priestly Imperial Prince Rinnojinomiya Kocho, Princess Taruko and others.
